name: Lil Nas X
description:
'''Montero Lamar Hill''' (born April 9, 1999), better known by his stage name '''Lil Nas X''' ({{IPAc-en|n|ɑː|z}} {{Respell|NAHZ}}), is an American rapper, singer and songwriter. He rose to prominence with the release of his 2018 [[country rap]] single "[[Old Town Road]]", which spent a [[List of Billboard Hot 100 chart achievements and milestones#Most weeks at number one|then-record 19 weeks]] atop the U.S. [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart. Simultaneously, he [[came out]] as [[homosexuality|gay]], the first artist to do so while having a number-one record.

Following the success of "Old Town Road", Lil Nas X signed with [[Columbia Records]] to release his debut [[extended play]] (EP) ''[[7 (Lil Nas X EP)|7]]'' (2019), which spawned two follow-up singles⁠: "[[Panini (song)|Panini]]" and "[[Rodeo (Lil Nas X and Cardi B song)|Rodeo]]" (remixed featuring [[Nas]]); the former peaked at number five on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]], while the latter peaked at number 22. His debut studio album, ''[[Montero (album)|Montero]]'' (2021), peaked at number two on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and earned a nomination for [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]] at the [[64th Annual Grammy Awards]]. It was supported by the ''Billboard'' Hot 100-number one singles "[[Montero (Call Me by Your Name)]]" and "[[Industry Baby]]" (featuring [[Jack Harlow]]), along with the top-ten single "[[Thats What I Want]]".

Known for his [[queer]] visuals and social media presence, Lil Nas X has received [[List of awards and nominations received by Lil Nas X|numerous accolades]], including two [[Grammy Award]]s, five [[Billboard Music Awards|''Billboard'' Music Awards]], five [[MTV Video Music Awards]], two [[BET Hip Hop Awards]], two [[iHeartRadio Music Awards]] and two [[American Music Awards]]. "Old Town Road" ranks as the [[List of best-selling singles in the United States|second highest-certified song in the United States]]—with 17 platinum certifications. He was placed on ''[[Forbes]]''{{'}} [[30 Under 30]] in 2020, and ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' named him one of the [[Time 100|100 most influential people in the world]] the following year. He became the youngest honoree in the [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]] in 2022 upon receiving the [[Hal David Starlight Award]] in May of that year.
